block.p: New Iraqi Missile Design Puts Panel in U.S. Corner A panel of arms experts advised United Nations inspectors that a missile in development by Iraq exceeds United Nations range limits. The panel's conclusion adds fuel to the Bush administration's argument that Iraq is defying Security Council disarmament resolutions.

The director of central intelligence, George J. Tenet, warned that the latest taped message attributed to Osama bin Laden was an ''exhortation to his followers,'' like statements made by the terrorist leader last year that were quickly followed by deadly attacks.

New Iraqi Missile Design Puts Panel in U.S. Corner A panel of arms experts advised United Nations inspectors that a missile in development by Iraq exceeds United Nations range limits. The panel's conclusion adds fuel to the Bush administration's argument that Iraq is defying Security Council disarmament resolutions.

The director of central intelligence, George J. Tenet, warned that the latest taped message attributed to Osama bin Laden was an ''exhortation to his followers,'' like statements made by the terrorist leader last year that were quickly followed by deadly attacks.

The government of Saudi Arabia has increased security around its oil fields and processing centers after the discovery that employees of the state-owned oil company sympathetic to Al Qaeda were discussing sabotage plans late last summer, American and Saudi officials said.

Senior members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee said they were deeply concerned that elements of Pakistan's government were helping to undermine the stability of Afghanistan, including by possibly sheltering Taliban fighters.

With some deft diplomatic maneuvering, President Vladimir V. Putin has vaulted Russia into the position of potential swing vote in a looming United Nations debate over military action against Iraq. Now comes something far more difficult: deciding which way to swing.

17 Killed in Afghanistan Afghan officials said 17 civilians had been killed in an American-led bombing of a mountainous region of southern Afghanistan, where American Special Forces have been fighting rebels since Monday. The fighting began when the Americans were attacked in an ambush.

Canadian Health Care Anger Complaints about long lines for diagnosis and surgery, as well as ''line-jumping'' by the affluent and connected, are eroding public confidence in Canada's national health care system and producing a leading issue for next year's national elections.

Court Opens Way to Try Sharon Belgium's highest court said that Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel could be tried for war crimes, but not as long as he enjoyed the immunity of his office. The ruling did allow a Belgian court to pursue the case against Mr. Sharon's co-defendant, Amos Yaron, the former Israeli Army chief of staff.

U.S. Drops Subsidy Plans Vice President Dick Cheney persuaded Congressional Republicans to drop plans for adding farm subsidies, trying to avoid a foreign trade dispute. The United States' trading partners gathered this week to discuss how to trim and eliminate farm subsidies. The United States would have faced a hostile reception had Congress approved new subsidy payments.

Warning About Shuttle Two Days Before Disaster One NASA engineer warned of the possibility of catastrophic consequences if damage from the foam insulation that struck the shuttle during liftoff allowed the heat of re-entry to penetrate the wheel well and burst the shuttle's tires.

Shortage of Terror Funds Many state and local governments say they are not prepared to deal with a major terrorist attack because of the failure of the federal government to provide billions of dollars in aid.
The rest of the country is not immune to the fears of terror felt by many in New York and Washington. But that fear is nowhere near as widespread, or as keenly felt.

Bush Clashes With Greenspan The White House moved quickly to shore up support for President Bush's economic plan and took the rare step of bluntly disagreeing with the Federal Reserve chairman over the need for an immediate new round of tax cuts.
Congressional Spending Deal Congressional negotiators reached a deal on a spending measure that finances most of the federal government through Sept. 30.
Favoritism in Admissions The favoritism that admissions offices show to legacies, as the children of alumni are called, and those with deep pockets is coming under fire as never before.
No Cameras in Texas Jury Room Texas's highest criminal appeals court ruled that cameras are not welcome in jury rooms there.

Christian Prison Program Suit Two federal lawsuits filed in Iowa contend that a state-financed evangelical Christian prison program that gives special privileges to participating inmates violates the separation of church and state.

Ban on Cellphone Use Praised by Actors New York city stage actors said they were pleased that the City Council banned cellphone use during public performances, including plays, movies and concerts, and in galleries and museums. The vote overrode a veto by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who had argued that the law would be nearly impossible to enforce.

Indian Pt. Report Criticized The chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission criticized a New York State-commissioned report on emergency planning at the Indian Point nuclear power plant in Westchester County, saying it possibly gave ''undue weight'' to the impact of a terrorist attack.

Day Care Workers Strike Nearly 7,000 day care workers staged a one-day strike protesting Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's demand that they accept lower raises than what most municipal employees received. The strike shut down 358 private centers that are financed largely by the city.
Agreements on Emissions Administration officials announced several modest agreements with a number of industries to voluntarily control the emissions of greenhouse gases linked to global warming.
New York to Sue Drugmakers New York state plans to sue two major drug companies, accusing them essentially of paying doctors and pharmacists to choose their drugs over competing medicines.

Enron's Tax Maneuvers In a report to the Senate Finance Committee, tax experts will explain that Enron and other big companies have avoided taxes by exploiting differences in the rules governing the two sets of books that all companies must keep, one for shareholders and the other for the I.R.S.

Shift Proposed at United United Airlines plans to shift about 30 percent of its domestic capacity into a new discount airline the carrier hopes to form as it tries to emerge from bankruptcy, executives said.
Editorials: Back to the United Nations; keep talking about Miguel Estrada; shutting down the snoops; how Albany drafts a media event.
